question: 6 (b)
sols_html:
The answer is True

Given \(A\vec{x} = \vec{b}\) then \(\vec{b} \in R(A)\) (i.e. is a vector in the range of A, or a vector b is in the span of A).

And \(\vec{y} \in N(A^T)\), meaning that y is in the nullspace of \(A^T\)

From the orthogonality of subspaces, we now that \(N(A^T) = R(A) ^\perp\)

Hence, \(\vec{y}^T \vec{b} = 0\) or \(< y, b> = 0\)
sols_latex:
The answer is True

Given $A\vec{x} = \vec{b}$ then $\vec{b} \in R(A)$ (i.e. is a vector in
the range of A, or a vector b is in the span of A).

And $\vec{y} \in N(A^T)$, meaning that y is in the nullspace of $A^T$

From the orthogonality of subspaces, we now that $N(A^T) = R(A) ^\perp$

Hence, $\vec{y}^T \vec{b} = 0$ or $< y, b> = 0$
sols_raw:
The answer is True

Given <math>A\vec{x} = \vec{b}</math> then <math>\vec{b} \in R(A)</math> (i.e. is a vector in the range of A, or a vector b is in the span of A).

And <math>\vec{y} \in N(A^T)</math>, meaning that y is in the nullspace of <math>A^T</math>

From the orthogonality of subspaces, we now that <math>N(A^T) = R(A) ^\perp</math>

Hence, <math>\vec{y}^T \vec{b} = 0</math> or <math>< y, b> = 0</math>
statement_html:
Determine if each of the following statements is true of false. Show reason or proof if true and show reason or counter example if false.

If

\[\begin{aligned} A\vec{x} &= \vec{b} \\ A^T \vec{y} &= 0\end{aligned}\]

then \(\vec{b} \perp \vec{y}\).
statement_latex:
Determine if each of the following statements is true of false. Show
reason or proof if true and show reason or counter example if false.

If

\begin{align*}
A\vec{x} &= \vec{b} \\
A^T \vec{y} &= 0
\end{align*}

then $\vec{b} \perp \vec{y}$.
statement_raw:
Determine if each of the following statements is true of false. Show reason or proof if true and show reason or counter example if false.

If

<math>
\begin{align}
A\vec{x} &= \vec{b} \\
A^T \vec{y} &= 0
\end{align}
</math> 

then <math>\vec{b} \perp \vec{y}</math>.
